section.title: Hardware Recommendations
section.para: Homegear runs on pretty much any computer running GNU/Linux. The only requirement is a minimum memory size of 256 MB. Recommended is 1 GB. The memory limits the number of threads that can run simultaneously. Some devices don't need threads and some devices do. So depending on what you want to do, you need more or less memory. 1 GB should be more than enough for all normal installations though.

note.para: It is recommended to use a battery backup for your system so there is no data corruption in case of a power blackout.

section.title: Software Requirements
section.para: Homegear should run on all current GNU/Linux distributions. With small changes it can also run on BSD and Mac OS systems.

warning.para: Do not run Homegear in a virtual machine as packet timing is very inaccurate.

section.title: Installing from Repository
section.para: If you are using Debian, Raspbian or Ubuntu you can install Homegear from repository. Please follow the instructions for your system.

section.title: Debian
section.para: Packages are provided for Debian 7 (Wheezy) and Debian 8 (Jessie). Supported architectures are i386, amd64, armel and armhf.

warning.para: Don't use the Debian repositories for Raspbian. Use the Raspbian repository instead.

section.title: Debian 7 (Wheezy)
section.para: Please run the following commands as root:
section.programlisting: wget https://homegear.eu/packages/Release.key && apt-key add Release.key && rm Release.key echo 'deb https://homegear.eu/packages/Debian/ wheezy/' >> /etc/apt/sources.list.d/homegear.list apt-get update apt-get install homegear
section.para: After installing Homegear, install any family modules you like. To install all family modules available, run:
section.programlisting: apt-get install homegear-homematicbidcos homegear-homematicwired homegear-insteon homegear-max homegear-philipshue homegear-sonos

section.title: Manually Install Debian/Raspbian/Ubuntu Package
section.para: Download the correct packages from the Homegear download page. You need at least the packages "libhomegear-base" and "homegear". Additionally download all family module packages you want to use. Then as root install the packages using dpkg:
section.programlisting: dpkg -i libhomegear-base_XXX.deb dpkg -i homegear_XXX.deb dpkg -i homegear-MODULENAME_XXX.deb

section.title: Raspbian Image
section.para: If you want to use Homegear on a Raspberry Pi, the easiest way is to download the Raspberry Pi image and write it to a SD card.
Follow the instructions on http://elinux.org/RPi_Easy_SD_Card_Setup#Flashing_the_SD_Card_using_Windows (for Windows, Mac and GNU/Linux) to get the image onto your SD card.
Username is: "pi" Password is: "raspberry"

SSH is enabled on port 22, so you can use a SSH client (e. g. PuTTY) to login and you don't need to connect a display and keyboard. You can try logging in using the hostname "homegearpi" or you need to look the IP address up in your DHCP server (or router). When you first login, the Raspberry Pi configuration tool will start.
